definition[0]: to be unable to swallow and feel as if you are about to bring up food from your stomach
example[0]: The foul smell made her gag.
example[1]: He almost gagged on his first mouthful of food.
definition[1]: to put a piece of cloth over someone’s mouth to stop them making a noise
example[2]: Thugs gagged her and tied her to a chair.
example[3]: He left his victim bound and gagged  (=tied up and with something over their mouth that stops them speaking).
definition[2]: to stop people saying what they want to say and expressing their opinions
example[4]: an attempt to gag political activists
example[6]: It was a bit of a running gag  (=a joke which is repeated) in the show.
definition[4]: a piece of cloth put over someone’s mouth to stop them making a noise
